choices.text: Salivary secretion is inhibited by nausea
Protect the oral cavity from bacteria

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient comes to the OPD and complains of sialorrhea. Which of the following statements is not true about salivary secretion
questions.solution:
Option A: Salivary secretion is mainly regulated by parasympathetic input. It is triggered by the reflex act of chewing, sight or smell of food. It is also promoted by nausea and inhibited by fear or during sleep.

Salivary secretion has a pH of 7.0 and neutralises acidity from stomach when gastric juice is regurgitated into esophagus in heartburn and relieves it.

The amylase in saliva partially digests starch.

IgA and lysozymes in saliva protect the oral cavity against bacteria.

Other options:

Option B: Salivary secretion relieves heartburn.

  • Saliva does help to neutralize stomach acid due to its bicarbonate content, which can provide temporary relief from heartburn symptoms.

Option C: It partially digests starch.

  • This statement is true. Saliva contains the enzyme amylase, which begins the digestion of starch into simpler sugars.

Option D: Protects the oral cavity from bacteria.

  • This statement is also true. Saliva contains antibacterial compounds, such as lysozyme and immunoglobulins, that help protect the oral cavity from pathogens.

Key takeaways:

Salivary secretion is regulated by parasympathetic input, triggered by stimuli like chewing or the sight of food, has a neutral pH of 7.0 to neutralize gastric acid during heartburn, contains amylase for starch digestion, and protects the oral cavity with IgA and lysozymes.

choices.text: Avoid large meals and those with high sugar concentrations
Have only one large meal in a day

questions.text: 45 year old male presented to the doctor with symptoms of weakness, dizziness and sweating after meals frequently. The patient was found to be hypoglycemic. He has a history of gastric bypass surgery. The doctor diagnosed the patient with dumping syndrome. What dietary modifications would the doctor suggest to the patient
questions.solution:
Option A: In gastric bypass surgery, a part of stomach is stapled and bypassed, this results in the loss of reservoir function of the stomach. Such a patient must eat small meals frequently.

Taking a large meal results in rapid absorption of glucose and hyperglycemia follows. This causes an abrupt rise in insulin and thus causes hypoglycemia.

Rapid entry of hypertonic bolus in intestine cause movement of water into the gut causing hypovolemia and hypotension. Thus hypertonicity in the gut should be avoided

Other options:

Option B: Have only one large meal in a day: This is counterproductive, as large meals can exacerbate dumping syndrome by causing rapid glucose absorption and hypoglycemia.

Option C: Increase sugar intake: Increasing sugar intake can worsen symptoms by promoting rapid absorption and subsequent hypoglycemia.

Option D: Decrease water intake: Decreasing water intake is not advisable, as hydration is important; instead, water should be consumed separately from meals to avoid exacerbating dumping syndrome.

Key takeaways:

Gastric bypass surgery requires patients to eat small, frequent meals to prevent rapid glucose absorption and dumping syndrome, which can cause hypoglycemia and hypotension.

questions.text: A mother brings her newborn baby to a pediatric with complaints of constant crying and vomiting. The baby was diagnosed with genetically reduced number of chief cells in the stomach. What would be the problem the baby might be facing?
questions.solution:
Option D: Peptic cells or chief cells secrete pepsinogen, which is converted to pepsin in the acidic pH of stomach and digests proteins.

Intrinsic factor responsible for B12 absorption and HCl responsible for the acidity of stomach are secreted of oxyntic or parietal cells.

Mucus that prevents ulceration of the mucosa is secreted by mucus neck cells.

Other options:

Option A: Difficulty in absorbing B12: This is primarily due to lack of intrinsic factor, produced by parietal cells, not chief cells.

Option B: Less acidity of the stomach: Chief cells do not directly affect stomach acidity, which is mainly regulated by parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid.

Option C: Ulceration of the gut mucosa: While low pepsin may affect digestion, it does not directly cause ulceration, which is more related to excess acid or other factors.

Key takeaways:

Chief cells secrete pepsinogen for protein digestion, while parietal cells produce intrinsic factor for B12 absorption and hydrochloric acid for acidity, with mucus neck cells preventing mucosal ulceration.

choices.text: Increase in mucus secretion in stomach
Decrease in mucus secretion in stomach

questions.text: A 13-year-old female complains of runny nose on exposure to pollen. She was diagnosed with pollen allergy, which is a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction. Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction is caused by increased release of histamine by the mast cells. An increase in histamine will chiefly cause which of the following
questions.solution:
Option A: Histamine acts on H2 receptors on the basolateral membrane and elevates intracellular cAMP. This activates protein kinase, which in turn increases the activity of H+/K+ ATPase. This results in increased H+ into the lumen and thus increased acidity

Other options:

  • Option B: Decrease in stomach acidity: Histamine stimulates acid secretion, so it does not cause a decrease in acidity.
  • Option C: Increase in mucus secretion in stomach: Histamine primarily increases acid secretion, not mucus secretion.
  • Option D: Decrease in mucus secretion in stomach: There is no direct link between histamine release and decreased mucus secretion; instead, mucus secretion is regulated by other factors.

Key takeaways:

Histamine binds to H2 receptors on parietal cells, increasing cAMP and activating H+/K+ ATPase, resulting in elevated stomach acidity.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male complains of burning sensation in the epigastric region, which is relieved after a meal. The patient was diagnosed with peptic ulcer. Which of the following will increase gastric secretion
questions.solution:
Presence of acid, fat, protein break down products and irritants cause the secretion of hormones from the intestine such as secretin, which inhibit the gastric secretion.

GIP - gastric inhibitory peptide and VIP - vasoactive intestinal polypeptide from the intestine also decrease the gastric secretion.

Somatostatin inhibits the G cells that secrete gastrin and the parietal cells with secrete HCl thus decreasing gastric secretion.

Option D: Ach acts on M3 receptors on the basolateral membrane of stomach and increases intra cellular calcium which in turn activates protein kinase which in turn increases the activity of H+/K+ ATPase and increases gastric secretion

Other options:

  • Option A: Secretin: Inhibits gastric secretion and promotes bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas and it also increases bile secretion.
  • Option B: GIP (Gastric Inhibitory Peptide): Inhibits gastric secretion, slows gastric emptying and increases insulin release.
  • Option C: Somatostatin: Decreases gastric acid and pepsinogen secretion, pancreatic and small intestinal secretion, gall bladder contraction and insulin release.

Key takeaways:

Acid, fat, and protein breakdown products stimulate the secretion of hormones like secretin, GIP, and somatostatin that inhibit gastric secretion, while Ach increases gastric secretion by activating M3 receptors, raising intracellular calcium, and enhancing H+/K+ ATPase activity.

questions.text: Your younger brother has a school project of finding out the pH of various substances. You are a medical student, find his litmus paper strips, and decide to experiment and find out the pH of body fluids. Which of the following would convert red litmus paper into blue?
questions.solution:
Option B: The pancreatic juice has a high HCO3- content making it alkaline.

The components are:

Other options:

  • Option A: Gastric juice: Acidic (pH 1.5-3.5), would turn blue litmus paper red.
  • Option C: Bile in gallbladder: Bile in the hepatic duct is alkaline, but in gall bladder bile is concentrated and its Ph is (7 to 7.4) may not strongly affect litmus.
  • Option D: Saliva: Slightly acidic to neutral (pH 6-7), would not change blue litmus paper to red.

Key takeaways:

Pancreatic juice is alkaline (with a pH around 8) and would turn red litmus paper blue, while gastric juice is acidic, bile can vary but is generally alkaline, and saliva is typically neutral to slightly acidic. So pancreatic juice is best among the options given.

questions.text: An obese 45-year-old female presents with a chief complaint of pain in the upper right part of abdomen. An analysis of the EHBA and liver was to be done. On checking the components of bile, which of the following would not be found
questions.solution:
Bile juice contains bile salts such as taurocholate, glycocholate. It also contains bile acids such as cholic acid, lithocholic acid, deoxycholic acid, chenodeoxycholic acid. Primary bile acids(cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid) are synthesized in liver while secondary bile acids(deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid) are created by bacteria in colon by dehydroxylation of primary bile acids. The bile pigments present in bile are bilirubin, biliverdin.

Option D: Stercobilin in not a component of bile. Bilirubin in the small intestine is converted to urobilinogen by the action of bacterial proteases which is then excreted as stercobilin in the feces, giving them colour.

Other options:

Option A: Bile salts: Present in bile, aiding fat digestion.

Option B: Bile pigments: Includes bilirubin, a major component.

Option C: Bilirubin: A waste product found in bile.

Key takeaways:

Bile contains bile salts, bile pigments (bilirubin and biliverdin), but stercobilin is formed in the intestine from bilirubin and excreted in feces, not found in bile itself.

questions.text: A patient presents with an upset stomach, vomiting and pain in the upper abdominal region. The patient admits of excessive alcohol use, and the CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of pancreatitis. Pancreatic juice rich in enzymes is secreted by
questions.solution:
Secretin acts in pancreatic duct to cause secretion of very alkaline rich in bicarbonate, which is poor in enzymes.

Option A: CCK on the acinar cells to cause the release of zymogen granules, which makes the pancreatic secretion rich in enzymes.

Histamine primarily acts on stomach to increase the secretion of HCl while somatostatin decreases the acidity of stomach.

Other options:

Option B: (Secretin): Stimulates bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas, but does not directly promote enzyme secretion.

Option C: (Histamine): Primarily involved in gastric acid secretion, not pancreatic enzyme secretion.

Option D: (Somatostatin): Inhibits the release of various hormones, including those stimulating pancreatic secretion, rather than promoting it.

Key takeaways:

CCK stimulates acinar cells to release enzyme-rich pancreatic juice, while secretin mainly promotes bicarbonate secretion

questions.text: A 32-year-old male complains of burning sensation in the epigastric region. On further history taking, he was found to be treated for gout some time ago. The patient was diagnosed with peptic ulcer, which was caused by the frequent use of NSAIDs. Which phase is responsible for the secretion of the most acid quantity from the stomach
questions.solution:
Option B: When food enters the stomach, the distension of stomach and presence of food results in the most prominent secretion in the stomach.

The cephalic phase is before the food actually enters the stomach. It is stimulated by the sight, smell or thought of food. It secretes comparatively less amount of acid.

The duodenal and intestinal phase mostly act as regulators of the acid secretion as presence of proteins in the duodenum can inhibit secretion of the stomach by secretin

Cephalic phase: 30 % of total gastric secretion

Gastric phase: 60 % of total gastric secretion

Intestinal phase: 10 % of total gastric secretion

Other options:

Option A: (Cephalic): This phase stimulates a smaller amount of acid secretion in response to sensory stimuli before food enters the stomach.

Option C: (Duodenal): This phase primarily regulates gastric emptying and secretion in response to chyme entering the duodenum, reducing acid secretion.

Option D: (Intestinal): This phase further decreases gastric acid secretion as the intestinal contents are processed.

Key takeaways:

The gastric phase secretes the most acid due to stomach distension and food presence, while the cephalic phase has a smaller role and the duodenal phase mainly regulates acid secretion.

questions.text: After secretion of trypsinogen from pancreas into the duodenum which of the following convert the enzyme into an active form trypsin?
questions.solution:
Option C: The pancreas secrete a number of enzymes that are in non-active form. They are all activated by trypsin in the small intestine. Trypsin itself is secreted as trypsinogen from the pancreas, which is activated by Enterokinase, which is secreted from the small intestine.

Option A: (Alkaline pH): It helps optimize enzyme function but does not activate trypsinogen.

Option B: (Chymotrypsin): This enzyme is activated by trypsin, not the activator of trypsinogen.

Option D: (Pancreatic lipase): Involved in fat digestion, not in activating trypsinogen.

Key takeaways:

Enteropeptidase(a/k/as enterokinase) from the small intestine activates trypsinogen to trypsin, which then activates other pancreatic enzymes.

questions.text: The I cells of the mucosa of upper intestine secretes an important compound. The actions of that compound are all, except which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option D: CCK is responsible for pancreatic enzyme secretion and contraction of the gallbladder and relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi, which allows both bile and pancreatic juice to flow into the intestinal lumen. It also inhibits gastric emptying and enhances the motility of small intestine and colon.

Other options:

Option A: (Contraction of gallbladder): CCK stimulates the gallbladder to contract and release bile.

Option B: (Stimulation of pancreatic secretion): CCK promotes pancreatic enzyme secretion for digestion.

Option C: (Inhibition of gastric emptying): CCK slows gastric emptying to optimize digestion in the small intestine.

Key takeaways:

CCK stimulates pancreatic enzyme secretion, gallbladder contraction, and intestinal motility while inhibiting gastric emptying and relaxing the sphincter of Oddi.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female, who has been dieting for three days, ends her fast by eating cookies. After eating food rich in sugars, insulin is secreted from the pancreas. Which of the following is not responsible for the secretion of insulin?
questions.solution:
Option D: GIP, gastrin and CCK, all stimulate the release of insulin from the pancreas. Somatostatin is released from the diesel of the pancreas. It inhibits the secretion of gastrin, GIP, secretin, VIP and Motililn.

Option A: (GIP): Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide stimulates insulin secretion in response to glucose.

Option B: (Gastrin): Primarily stimulates gastric acid secretion, but can also enhance insulin secretion indirectly.

Option C: (CCK): Cholecystokinin stimulates insulin release in response to fats and proteins.

Key takeaways:

GIP, gastrin, and CCK stimulate insulin release, while somatostatin inhibits insulin secretion and other gastrointestinal hormones.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has been trying to lose weight, but he enjoyed eating so much that he found it difficult to do so. He then reads about a product in the popular press, which guarantees that he can lose weight, as caloric intake due to starch ingestion will be reduced (a starch blocker). The over-the-counter product that he buys is claimed to inhibit which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Option C: Starch blockers contain a natural inhibitor of salivary amylase, which will block starch digestion in the mouth. The starch blocker would only inhibit the other amylase that digests starch, pancreatic amylase, if the inhibitor would survive the conditions of the acidic stomach without becoming denatured.

Option A: Intestinal enteropeptidase: This enzyme activates pancreatic enzymes for protein digestion, not starch.

Option B: Pancreatic lipase: This enzyme digests fats, not starches.

Option D: Gastric amylase: While there is amylase in gastric juice, it is not a primary enzyme for starch digestion as it is inactivated by stomachs acidic ph. salivary amylase is more significant in the initial digestion of starches.

Key takeaways:

A starch blocker would inhibit salivary amylase, which is the enzyme responsible for breaking down starches into simpler sugars in the mouth. By inhibiting this enzyme, the product would reduce the breakdown of starches and thus decrease caloric intake from carbohydrate sources.

choices.text: Difficulty in passage of food from esophagus to stomach

questions.text: During the placement of an NG tube, the Lower esophageal sphincter of a patient was found to be deficient in myenteric plexus. The release of NO and VIP is defective. What kind of abnormalities would the patient face?
questions.solution:
Option B: The absence of myenteric plexus and  NO and VIP causes the resting tone of lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to be increased. These results in non-relaxation of the LES called achalasia. The tight sphincter will cause difficulty in passage of food from esophagus to stomach. It causes indigestion and infection in the lower esophagus

GERD is the opposite condition where incompetent LES allows acid reflux into the esophagus. It can cause heart burn and infection in the lower esophagus with ulceration.

Since the food cannot pass down from esophagus in achalasia, it is expelled out by vomiting reflex.

Diarrhea is caused by increased intestinal motility.

Other options:

Option A: GERD: While a deficient LES can contribute to GERD, the primary issue here is difficulty in food passage due to impaired motility, not reflux.

Option C: Decreased vomiting reflex: The myenteric plexus primarily affects gut motility; it does not directly cause decreased vomiting reflex.

Option D: Frequent diarrhea: This is unrelated to the condition described, as it primarily involves esophageal motility rather than intestinal function.

Key takeaways:

Absence of the myenteric plexus and reduced NO and VIP leads to increased lower esophageal sphincter tone, causing achalasia and difficulty in food passage, unlike GERD, where the sphincter is incompetent.

questions.text: A patient presents with the chief complain of frequent diarrhea. On analysis, there was no inflammation of the GIT but the basal electrical rhythm of the GIT was increased. Which of the following is the pacemaker of GIT?
questions.solution:
Option C: Smooth muscles of the GIT has spontaneous rhythmic fluctuations in the membrane potential between -65 and -45 mV. This basic electrical rhythm is initiated by interstitial cells of cajal, which are also known as the pacemaker cells.

ECL cells secrete histamine.

Oxyntic cell, secret HCl and intrinsic factor in the stomach

G cells secrete gastrin in the stomach.

Rate of BER at different parts of GIT: Duodenum(12)>jejunum(11)>ileum(8)>sigmoid(6)>stomach(4)>caecum(2).

Other options:

Option A: (ECL cells): Secrete histamine, which stimulates gastric acid secretion, but do not act as pacemakers.

Option B: (Oxyntic cells): Secrete HCl and intrinsic factor in the stomach, not responsible for rhythmic contractions.

Option D: (G cells): Secrete gastrin, which stimulates gastric motility but is not the pacemaker for GIT rhythms.

Key takeaways:

The interstitial cells of Cajal are the pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal tract, initiating the basic electrical rhythm, while ECL cells, oxyntic cells, and G cells have distinct secretion functions.

choices.text: Congenital absence of ganglion cells in both myenteric plexus and submucosal plexus of a segment of distant colon
Paralysis of colonic smooth muscles due to trauma during parturition

questions.text: An infant visits a pediatric presenting with symptoms of abdominal distension, anorexia, and lassitude. He was diagnosed with Hirsch sprung disease. What is the cause of Hirsch sprung disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: Some children have a genetically determined condition of abnormal colonic motility known as Hirschsprung disease or aganglionic megacolon, which is characterized by abdominal Distension, anorexia, and lassitude. Distension of segment proximal to aganglionic segment is seen. The disease is typically diagnosed in infancy, and affects as many as 1 in 5000 live births.

It is due to a congenital absence of the ganglion cells in both the myenteric and submucous plexuses of a segment of the distal colon, as a result of failure of the normal cranial-to-caudal migration of neural crest cells during development.

Option B: (Congenital absence of colon): This would lead to severe gastrointestinal issues but is not the specific cause of Hirschsprung disease.

Option C: (Hyperactivity of colon smooth muscles): This would not explain the symptoms; Hirschsprung disease involves an absence of ganglion cells, leading to decreased motility.

Option D: (Paralysis of colonic smooth muscles due to trauma during parturition): Trauma can affect nerves, but Hirschsprung disease specifically results from a congenital lack of ganglion cells.

Key takeaways:

Hirschsprung disease is caused by the congenital absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric and submucosal plexuses of the distal colon, leading to symptoms like abdominal distension and anorexia.

questions.text: Your friend is suffering from constipation since 3 days. He is concerned about the side effects of drugs and does not want to take one. As a medical student what would you advice your friend other than prescribing drugs?
questions.solution:
Option D: Most cases of constipation are relieved by a change in the diet to include more fiber, or the use of laxatives that retain fluid in the colon, thereby increasing the bulk of the stool and promoting reflexes that lead to evacuation.

Mechanism: High dietary fibers soften the stool and increases the bulk to produce appropriate defecation reflex. Laxatives loosen the stool and help in constipation.

As noted above, lubiprostone has recently joined the armamentarium for the treatment of constipation, and is assumed to act by enhancing chloride, and thus water, secretion into the colon thereby increasing the fluidity of the colonic contents.

Option C: (Decreased fiber intake) would exacerbate constipation.

Key takeaways:

Constipation is often relieved by increasing dietary fiber or using laxatives that retain fluid in the colon, enhancing stool bulk and promoting evacuation.

questions.text: In a period between meals, the intestine is relatively quiescent, but every 90 minutes it is swept through by a large peristaltic wave. Which hormone is responsible for such peristaltic wave?
questions.solution:
Option D: In the period between meals, the intestine is relatively quiescent but every 90 minutes it is swept through by a large peristaltic wave triggered by hormone motilin. The migratory motor complex (MMC) presumably serves a housekeeping function. MMC also known as hunger/housekeeping contractions. MMC progress at a rate of 5cm/min.

Option A: (Somatostatin): This hormone inhibits gastric acid secretion and other gastrointestinal functions but does not stimulate peristalsis.

Option B: (Secretin): Primarily regulates water homeostasis and bicarbonate secretion in the pancreas but does not trigger peristaltic waves.

Option C: (Nitrous oxide): it is not the primary hormone responsible for the migrating motor complex.

Key takeaways:

Motilin is responsible for triggering the large peristaltic waves (migrating motor complex) that occur in the intestine approximately every 90-120 minutes during the fasting state.

choices.text: The breath is held in mid inspiration

questions.text: A person goes to Mount Abu for three days which he had several bouts of vomiting. He was diagnosed with motion sickness, which was the cause of his vomiting. Which of the following is not correct about the changes that occur during Vomiting?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vomiting is an example of central regulation of gut motility functions. Vomiting starts with salivation and the sensation of nausea. Reverse peristalsis empties material from the upper part of the small intestine into the stomach. The glottis closes, preventing aspiration of vomitus into the trachea. The breath is held in mid inspiration. The muscles of the abdominal wall contract, and because the chest is held in a fixed position, the contraction increases intra-abdominal pressure. The lower esophageal sphincter and the esophagus relax, and the gastric contents are ejected.

Option B: (The lower esophageal sphincter relaxes): This is correct; the lower esophageal sphincter relaxes to allow the contents to move from the stomach into the esophagus.

Option C: (Abdominal muscles contract): This is also correct; contraction of the abdominal muscles helps to forcefully expel the stomach contents during vomiting.

Option D: (The breath is held in mid-inspiration): This is correct; holding the breath during vomiting helps to prevent aspiration.

Key takeaways:

Vomiting is a regulated process involving salivation, nausea, reverse peristalsis, glottis closure to prevent aspiration, abdominal contraction to increase pressure, and relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter to expel gastric contents.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male complains of changes in bowel habits, bloody diarrhea, severe abdominal pain, and weight loss. A diagnosis of crohn's disease was made. As a part of treatment, hundred centimeter of the terminal ileum was resected. The patient will likely develop malabsorption of which of the following.
questions.solution:
Option A: The location of maximum absorption of bile is in the terminal ileum therefore; its absorption would be poor.

Option B: Iron is absorbed primarily in the duodenum and proximal jejunum, not the terminal ileum.

Option C: Lactose is digested in the small intestine but is not directly affected by ileal resection.

Option D: Protein absorption occurs mainly in the jejunum, so terminal ileum resection does not significantly impact it.

Key takeaways:

Resection of the terminal ileum can lead to malabsorption of bile salts, which are normally absorbed in that region, resulting in fat malabsorption. Absorption of B12 also occurs in ileum.

questions.text: A young man suffered trauma to ileum, and jejunum and therefore the entire ileum and partial jejunum was removed. Which of the following would the patient most likely suffer from?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vitamin B12 is mostly absorbed from the terminal part of small intestine and its removal would cause decreased absorption of vitamin B12.

Gastric ulcer is caused by the degradation of the mucosal cover of the stomach or hyperactive acidity.

Lactose intolerance is due to the lack of the activity of intestinal lactase.

Option B: (Gastric ulcer): This is related to stomach issues, not the ileum or jejunum.

Option C: (Lactose intolerance): Lactose digestion occurs in the small intestine, but enzyme deficiency (lactase) rather than structural damage causes intolerance.

Option D: (None of the above): Removal of the ileum would indeed cause Vitamin B12 deficiency, so this option is incorrect.

Key takeaways:

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum, so its removal leads to deficiency. Gastric ulcers are due to stomach issues, and lactose intolerance is caused by lactase deficiency, not intestinal removal.

choices.text: Food rich in trans fatty acids

questions.text: A patient with history of celiac disease comes to your clinic presenting a pattern of deficiencies indicating malabsorption syndrome. What would be the possible change in diet plan that you would suggest with the symptomatic treatments?
questions.solution:
Option A: Celiac disease occurs in genetically predisposed individuals in whom gluten and closely related proteins cause intestinal T cells to mount an inappropriate immune response that damages the intestinal epithelial cells and results in a loss of villi and a flattening of the mucosa associated with crypt hyperplasia. In celiac disease, the mucosa returns to normal if foods containing gluten are strictly excluded from the diet, although this may be difficult to achieve.

Foods containing gluten: Barley, rice, oats, wheat (BROW).

Antigliadin/antiendomyseal/antiTTG antibodies are produced in celiac disease.

HLA association: HLADQ2

Option B: (Food rich in proteins): While beneficial, it doesn't address the underlying gluten issue in celiac disease.

Option C: (Carbohydrate-rich foods): Many carbohydrates can contain gluten, which would exacerbate symptoms.

Option D: (Food rich in trans fatty acids): Trans fats are generally unhealthy and do not help with malabsorption or celiac disease management.

Key takeaways:

Patients with celiac disease must avoid gluten to manage malabsorption and prevent symptoms.

questions.text: A patient comes to your clinic presenting the symptoms of bloating, pain, gas and diarrhea. He complains that these symptoms appear after ingestion of dairy products. Which enzyme deficiency would cause the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option A: The patient is suffering from lactose intolerance. The patient is deficient in lactase, which is responsible for his intolerance to milk and its products. The milk and its products is not digested with results in bloating, pain, gas and diarrhea produced by the unabsorbed osmoles that are subsequently digested by colonic bacteria.

Option B: (Rennin): This enzyme is involved in milk coagulation in infants and does not relate to symptoms in adults.

Option C: (Pepsin): It aids in protein digestion in the stomach and does not affect lactose digestion.

Option D: (Renin): This Hormone is involved in blood pressure regulation and has no role in digestion.

Key takeaways:

Lactase deficiency causes lactose intolerance, leading to bloating, gas, pain, and diarrhea from undigested lactose fermented by colonic bacteria.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents with bleeding gums, petechiae and anemia. The doctor diagnosed him with scurvy. Which of the following Vitamin deficiency leads to scurvy?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic acid deficiency leads to dermatitis, enteritis, nutritional melalgia (burning foot syndrome), alopecia. Folic acid deficiency leads to neural tube defects in children born to folate deficient woman. Biotin deficiency leads to dermatitis, enteritis, hallucinations.

Option C: Ascorbic acid deficiency leads to scurvy.

Option A: (Pantothenic acid): Involved in energy metabolism, but its deficiency does not cause scurvy.

Option B: (Folic acid): Essential for DNA synthesis and red blood cell formation; its deficiency can cause anaemia but not scurvy.

Option D: (Biotin): Important for fatty acid metabolism and glucose production; deficiency leads to skin issues and hair loss, not scurvy.

Key takeaways:

Pantothenic acid, folic acid, and biotin deficiencies cause dermatitis and other issues, while ascorbic acid deficiency specifically leads to scurvy.

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of pigmentation of skin, pancreatic damage and cirrhosis of liver. The doctor diagnosed him with bronze diabetes or hemosiderosis. What would be the possible cause of this disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: Iron overload is the reason for hemosiderosis. It is the accumulate of iron in tissues. Melanin deficiency causes vitiligo. Magnesium toxicity results in hypotension, nausea, fatigue etc. Fluorine toxicity results in abdominal pain, diarrhea, drooling etc.

Option B: (Magnesium toxicity): This can cause various health issues but is not related to bronze diabetes. It produces muscle weakness, hypotension etc.

Option C: (Melanin deficiency): This would lead to lighter skin, not pigmentation or hemosiderosis.

Option D: (Fluorine toxicity): While harmful, it does not cause symptoms associated with iron overload or bronze diabetes.

Key takeaways:

Bronze diabetes or hemosiderosis is caused by excessive iron accumulation in the body, leading to skin pigmentation, pancreatic damage that leads to diabetes and liver cirrhosis.

questions.text: An infant is diagnosed with congenital absence of enterokinase. What would be likely complication due to this congenital defect?
questions.solution:
Option B: Trypsinogen is converted to the active enzyme trypsin by enterokinase when the pancreatic juice enters the duodenum. Enterokinase contains 41% polysaccharide, and this high polysaccharide content apparently prevents it from being digested itself before it can exert its effect. Trypsin converts chymotrypsinogen into chymotrypsin and other proenzymes into active enzymes. Trypsin can also activate trypsinogen therefore, once some trypsin is formed, there is an autocatalytic chain reaction. Enterokinase deficiency occurs as a congenital abnormality and leads to protein malnutrition. Trypsin digests proteins.

Option A: (Carbohydrate malabsorption): This is primarily affected by deficiencies in enzymes like amylase, not enterokinase, so carbohydrate absorption remains largely intact.

Option C: (Fats malabsorption): Fat digestion relies on lipases, which are not directly affected by the absence of enterokinase; therefore, fat absorption would not be significantly impacted.

Option D: (Vitamin B12 malabsorption): This is usually related to intrinsic factor or conditions affecting the terminal ileum, not enterokinase, so vitamin B12 absorption remains unaffected.

Key takeaways:

Enterokinase activates trypsinogen to trypsin in the duodenum; its deficiency disrupts protein digestion, leading to protein malnutrition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient comes to clinic presenting with symptoms similar to jaundice. He also has been diagnosed with gallstone through ultrasonography and CT scan. What would be the most possible type of jaundice that the patient would have?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gallstones that obstruct bile outflow from the liver can result in obstructive jaundice. If the flow of bile out of the liver is completely blocked, substances normally excreted in the bile, such as cholesterol, accumulate in the bloodstream. The interruption of the enterohepatic circulation of bile acids also induces the liver to synthesize bile acids at a greater rate. Some of these bile acids can be excreted by the kidney, and thus represent a mechanism for indirect excretion of at least a portion of cholesterol. However, retained biliary constituents may also cause liver toxicity. Kernicterus occur in infants, which have underdeveloped blood brain barrier.

Option B: (Hemolytic jaundice): This occurs due to increased breakdown of red blood cells, leading to excess bilirubin production, not related to gallstones.

Option C: (Hepatic jaundice): This results from liver cell damage affecting bilirubin metabolism, not from obstruction by gallstones.

Option D: (Kernicterus): This is a specific type of bilirubin-induced neurological damage seen in infants, not related to adult jaundice or gallstones.

Key takeaways:

Obstructive jaundice occurs when gallstones block bile outflow from the liver, causing bilirubin and cholesterol accumulation in the bloodstream and potential liver toxicity.
